questions.text: Figure is showing development of inferior venacava. Part of IVC marked with number 4 derived from which of the following vein?
questions.solution:
Development of the inferior vena cava:

Below upwards part of IVC developed from:

  1. Right posterior cardinal vein (sacrocardinal segment)
  2. Supracardinal vein.
  3. Supracardinal-subcardinal anastomosis
  4. Right subcardinal vein (renal segment).
  5. Anastomotic channel between subcardinal vein and right hepatocardiac channel
  6. Right hepatocardiac channel (hepatic segment).

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology, Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 265

questions.text: Figure is showing the development of placenta. Identify the marked cell of embryo.
questions.solution:
Formation of trabeculae and intervillous spaces:

  • The cells of trophoblast (made up of single layer of cells) proliferate, move on the surface, and lose their cell membranes to form a continuous sheet of cytoplasm containing many nuclei. This sheet/layer is called syncytiotrophoblast.
  • Thus, trophoblast is differentiated into two layers:
    • A deep layer called cytotrophoblast
    • A superficial layer called syncytiotrophoblast.
  • The syncytiotrophoblast grows rapidly and erodes the decidua basalis, and becomes thick.
  • The small cavities (lacunae) appear in thickened syncytiotrophoblast.
  • The syncytiotrophoblast continues to erode the decidua basalis. The lacunae increase in size. They lie radially around the developing embryo (blastocyst).
  • They are separated from each other by portions of syncytiotrophoblast termed trabeculae (villous primordia).
  • As the syncytiotrophoblast further grows it erodes the blood vessels of the endometrium and the blood enters into the lacunae along with the secretions of the endometrial glands.
  • Later the lacunae communicate with each other around the trabeculae and form the intervillous spaces. Thus, each trabeculus gets surrounded all around by the blood-filled space in the endometrium.

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology, Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition page Number - 97, 98

questions.text: Which of the following structure passing through marked area?
questions.solution:
Marked structure is foramen ovale:

  • The foramen ovale is large and oval in shape.
  • It is situated posterolateral to the upper end of the posterior border of lateral pterygoid plate
  • The foramen ovale transmits (mnemonic-MALE)
    • The mandibular nerve
    • The accessory meningeal artery
    • The lesser petrosal nerve
    • An emissary vein connecting the cavernous sinus with the pterygoid plexus of veins.
    • Anterior trunk of middle meningeal vein (occasionally).

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-3, 9th Edition, Page Number - 16, 19

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is being tested in the figure below?
questions.solution:
Clinical testing of pectoralis major:

  • The clavicular head is made prominent by flexing the arm to a right angle.
  • The sternocostal head can be tested by extending the flexed arm against resistance.
  • The sternocostal head is made prominent by abducting arm to 60° and then touching the opposite hip.
  • Pressing the fists against each other makes the whole muscle prominent.
  • Lifting a heavy rod makes clavicular part prominent (right arm).
  • Depressing a heavy rod shows sternocostal part as prominent (left arm).

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 48

questions.text: Identify the vertebra.
questions.solution:
Atypical thoracic vertebra:

  • First Thoracic Vertebra:
    • The body of this vertebra resembles that of a cervical vertebra.
    • It is broad and not heart-shaped.
    • Its upper surface is lipped laterally and bevelled anteriorly.
    • The superior costal facet on the body is complete. It articulates with the head of the first rib.
    • The inferior costal facet is a 'demifacet' for the second rib.
  • Ninth Thoracic Vertebra
    • The ninth thoracic vertebra resembles a typical thoracic vertebra except that the body has only the superior costal demifacets.
    • The inferior costal facets are absent.
    • Facet on transverse process is flat on T7-T10 vertebrae.
  • Tenth Thoracic Vertebra
    • The tenth thoracic vertebra resembles a typical thoracic vertebra except that the body has a single complete superior costal facet on each side, extending onto the root of the pedicle.
  • Eleventh Thoracic Vertebra
    • The body has a single large costal facet on each side, extending onto the upper part of the pedicle
    • The transverse process is small, and has no articular facet.
  • Twelfth Thoracic Vertebra
    • The shapes of the body, pedicles, transverse processes and spine are similar to those of a lumbar vertebra.
    • However, the body bears a single costal facet on each side, which lies more on the lower part of the pedicle than on the body.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 235, 236

questions.text: All of the following muscles get attached to marked area of femur in figure below, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Marked structure is Greater trochanter of femur:

  • This is a large quadrangular prominence located at the upper part of the junction of neck with the shaft.
  • The upper border of the trochanter lies at the level of the centre of the head.
  • The greater trochanter has an upper border with an apex, and three surfaces, anterior, medial and lateral.
  • The apex is the inturned posterior part of the posterior border.
  • The anterior surface is rough in its lateral part.
  • The medial surface presents a rough impression above, and a deep trochanteric fossa below.
  • The lateral surface is crossed by an oblique ridge directed downwards and forwards.
  • The following are attached to the greater trochanter.
    • The piriformis is inserted into the apex.
    • The gluteus minimus is inserted into the rough lateral part of the anterior surface.
    • The obturator internus and the two gemelli are inserted into the upper rough impression on medial surface.
    • The obturator externus is inserted into the trochanteric fossa.
    • The gluteus medius is inserted into the ridge on the lateral surface.
    • The trochanteric bursa of the gluteus maximus lies behind the ridge.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 16, 18, 19

questions.text: 65 years old man came in OPD after presenting with sensory loss over the skin of hand as shown in figure in pink colour. Which of the following nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
Superficial branch of Radial nerve:

  • The superficial terminal branch of the radial nerve (C6-C8) arises in front of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.
  • It descends through the upper two-thirds of the forearm lateral to the radial artery, and then passes posteriorly about 7 cm above the wrist.
  • While winding round the radius it pierces the deep fascia and divides into four or five small dorsal digital nerves.
  • In all, the superficial terminal branch supplies the skin of the lateral half of the dorsum of the hand, and the dorsal surfaces of the lateral 2½ digits including the thumb, except for the terminal portions supplied by the median nerve.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 89, 145

questions.text: 60 years old male patient came to OPD with C/O paralysis and atrophy of tongue. When he was asked to protude the tongue doctor found as shown in figure. Which of the following nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
• The hypoglossal nerve is tested clinically by asking the patient to protrude his/her tongue.
  • Normally, the tongue is protruded straight forwards.
  • If the nerve is paralysed, the tongue deviates to the paralysed side.
  • An infranuclear unilateral lesion of the hypoglossal nerve produces paralysis of the tongue on that side.
    • There is gradual atrophy of the paralysed half of the tongue.
    • The tongue looks shrunken.
    • On protrusion of tongue, its tip deviates to paralysed side as normal genioglossus muscle pulls the base towards normal side.
  • Bilateral paralysis of XII nerves results in complete paralysis of the tongue. Protrusion of tongue is not possible.
  • Speech and swallowing are affected, taste and touch sensations are normal.
  • Supranuclear lesions of the hypoglossal nerve cause paralysis without wasting.
    • The tongue moves sluggishly resulting in defective speech.
    • On protrusion, the tongue deviates to opposite side.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-4, 9th Edition, Page Number - 95, 96

questions.text: Figure is showing dermatomes of anterior abdominal wall. The area marked with arrow is supplied by which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous nerves of anterior abdominal wall:

  • The skin of the anterior abdominal wall is supplied by the lower six thoracic nerves (lower five intercostal and subcostal) and by the first lumbar nerve in the following manner.
  • The anterior cutaneous nerves (seven in number) are derived from the lower five intercostal nerves, the subcostal nerve and the iliohypogastric nerve (L1).
  • T7-T12 nerves enter the abdominal wall from the intercostal spaces.
    • They pass between internal oblique and transversus muscle, pierce the posterior lamina of internal oblique aponeurosis to enter rectus sheath.
    • Within the sheath, they pass behind rectus abdominis, then pierce the rectus muscles and the anterior wall of the rectus sheath close to the median plane, divide into medial and lateral branches and supply the skin of the front of the abdomen.
  • They are arranged in serial order;
    • T7 near the xiphoid process
    • T10 at the level of umbilicus,
    • The iliohypogastric nerve 2.5 cm above the superficial inguinal ring, and others at proportionate distances between them.
    • Subcostal nerve supplies pyramidalis while iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal do not enter rectus sheath. Iliohypogastric becomes cutaneous 2.5 cm above the superficial inguinal ring.
    • The terminal part of the ilioinguinal nerve emerges through the superficial inguinal ring, pierces the external spermatic fascia and descends to supply the skin of the external genitalia and the upper part of the medial side of the thigh.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 235, 237

questions.text: Figure is showing the histology of eyeball. Numbers are given from outer to inner side. Identify the layer marked with number 5.
questions.solution:
Histology of Eyeball:

  • The wall of the retina is made up of 10 layers as follows:
  • Sclera, made up of collagen fibres
  • Choroid, containing blood vessels and pigment cells.
  • The remaining layers are subdivisions of the retina
    • Pigment cell layer
    • Layer of rods and cones
    • Outer nuclear layer
    • Outer plexiform layer
    • Inner nuclear layer
    • Inner plexiform layer
    • Layer of ganglion cells
    • Layer of opti c nerve fibres.

Reference: I. B. Singh's textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 293, 294

choices.text: Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparring

questions.text: Lesion at site 'B' would produce which of the following type of visual defect?
questions.solution:
Lesions affecting the optic chiasm destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas that carry vision from the temporal fields of the respective sides and produce a heteronymous bitemporal hemianopia.


A- left eye blindness

B- bitemporal heteronymous hemianopia

C- homonymous hemianopia

D- homonymous hemianopia with macular sparring

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number:185

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be calculated using the spirometer
questions.solution:
Through spirometry, residual volume cannot be measured. Therefore, virtue of this FRC and TLC also cannot be measured through spirometry.

Residual volume

It is the amount of air remaining in the lungs. After maximum expiration, it keeps the alveoli inflated between breaths. It cannot be measured by a spirometer

Functional residual capacity. It is the amount of air remaining in the lungs. After or normal tidal expiration, it cannot be measured by a spirometer

Total lung capacity, it is the maximum amount of air. The lung can contain it cannot be measured by a spirometer

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number:593

questions.text: An anemic patient, on examination showed nails as in the picture. What would be the morphology of the patient is RBCs?
questions.solution:
The picture shows koilonychias, I.e., spooning of nails that is a hallmark of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron is essential for hemoglobin synthesis and hence, its deficiency causes reduction in hemoglobin synthesis and the RBCs are Microcytic and hypochromic.

Also in Thalassemia RBCs are Microcytic hypochromic

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number 527

choices.text: Opening of Na+ channels and influx of Na+
Opening of K+ channels and efflux of K+
Opening of Ca++ channels and ca++ influx
Slow opening of K+ channels, and opening of Ca++ channels

questions.text: What is the cause of "c" in above shown image of action potential?
questions.solution:
"C" represents repolarization in the nerve, i.e., decrease in positivity.

The influx of Na will cause depolarization by increasing the positivity inside the cell.

Calcium being a positive ion also cannot repolarize the cell. Ca++ influx is greatly responsible for cardiac muscle contraction.

Slow opening of K+ and influx of Ca++ causes the plateau phase in the ventricular muscle contraction.

The efflux of K+ is largely responsible for repolarization

"a" represents RMP

"b" represents depolarization

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, Page number:85

questions.text: What does the QT interval represent?
questions.solution:
The QT interval represents ventricular depolarization and depolarization. During this interval, the ventricles contract and relax thereafter.

Atrial systole is indicated by p wave

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, page number:494

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of pain and contralateral paralysis
Contralateral loss of pain and contralateral paralysis

questions.text: What would be the probable abnormalities due to the lesion in the tract below decussation shown in above image?
questions.solution:
Damage to the corticospinal tract below discussion (in spinal cord) produces weakness in muscles of the same side of body.

questions.text: Explain the cause of the above abnormality typically seen in-patient with hyperthyroidism.
questions.solution:
Exophthalmos is typically seen in mild degree in all patients with hyperthyroidism. It is caused due to edematous swelling in retrorbital tissues and degenerative changes in extraocular muscles. Often antibodies are seen against extraocular muscles and blood TSI levels are high

[Previous year topic

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for the event marked by "a" in the figure
questions.solution:
The marked arrow indicates proliferation of endometrium that happens under the influence of estrogen from the developing follicle.

Progesterone from corpus luteum maintains the edematous endometrium.

LH stimulates ovulation and estrogen and progesterone secretion

FSH promotes the growth of follicles.

Reference: Ganong's review of medical physiology, 23rd edition, page number:412

questions.text: Name the structure marked as Black arrow in this given image
questions.solution:
Fluid Mosaic Model of Biomembranes.

  • Proposed by Singer and Nicolson in 1972.
  • The membrane consist of bimolecular lipid bilayer with proteins inserted in it or bound to either surface

Membrane Proteins

  • Membranes Contain Integral and Peripheral Proteins.

Integral Protein

  • Deeply embedded (to both hydrophilic and hydro- phobic portions) in the lipid bilayer
  • Usually globular and are themselves amphipathic

Trans membrane integral protein are the proteins that span the whole lipid bilayer.

Peripheral Proteins

  • Attached to the Hydrophilic portions of Plasma membrane

Reference: DM Vasudevan, S Sreekumari 8edition/page number:13-14

questions.text: Following is a structure of Lipoprotein, which look like:
questions.solution:
Lp(a)

  • Almost silmilar to LDL.
  • Apo (a) is attached to apo B100 by disulphide
  • Major site of clearance of Lp(a) is
  • Strongly associated with Atherosclerosis and Myocardial infarction.
  • Significant homology with
  • It interferes with activation of Plasminogen to
  • Hence fibrin clot is no lysed.
  • Susceptible to Intravascular

Reference: MN Chatterjea and Rana Shinde 8th edition /Page number:448

questions.text: Following is an electrophoresis pattern of Lipoprotein. Which of the following is present at Anode region?
questions.solution:
Electrophoretic separation of lipoproteins


Separation of lipoproteins in an electric field depends on the protein content

  • Higher the protein content faster the mobility of lipoprotein in the electric field.
  • Chylomicron with least protein content remains at the origin and HDL with highest protein content moves fastest.
  • An exception is VLDL and IDL with less protein content moves ahead of LDL.

Reference: Harpers illustrated biochemistry 30edition/Page number:254

questions.text: Following is the pathway for synthesis of bile acids. Which of the following is a starting material?
questions.solution:
Starting material-Cholesterol

Bile Acids and its Site of Synthesis

Primary Bile acids - Liver

They are:

  • Cholic Acid( Most abundant bile acids in mammals)
  • Chenodeoxycholic Acid or Chenic acid

Secondary Bile acids - Intestine

They are:

  • Deoxycholic Acid
  • Lithocholic Acid

Synthesis of Primary Bile Acids In the Liver First step:

Cholesterol converted to 7 Hydrocholesterol by 7 a Hydroxylase, a microsomal Cyt P450 enzyme designated as CYP7A1.

A typical monooxygenase requires oxygen, NADPH and Vitamin C.

This is the rate limiting step.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30edition/Page number:258

questions.text: Which of the following important transport mechanism
questions.solution:
The co-transport system may either be a symport or an antiport. In symport, the transporter carries two solutes in the same direction across the membrane, e.g. sodium dependent glucose transporter.

The antiport system carries two solutes or ions in opposite direction, e.g. sodium pump

Uniport system carries single solute across the membrane, e.g. glucose transporter in most of the cells.

Reference: DM Vasudevan, S Sreekumari 8edition/page number: 18

choices.text: Coproporphyrinogen III then enters the mitochondria, where it is converted to protoporphyrinogen III
Mitochondrial enzyme coproporphyrinogen oxidase catalyzes the decarboxylation and oxidation of two propionic side chains to form protoporphyrinogen
Coproporphyrinogen oxidase enzyme is able to act on type-III as well as type- I coproporphyrinogen

questions.text: All of the following sentences are true about this heme synthesis reactions except.
questions.solution:
Coproporphyrinogen oxidase enzyme is able to act ONLY on type-III coproporphyrinogen

Conversion of Uroporphyrinogen to Protoporphyrin by Uroporphyrinogen Decarboxylase

  • Uroporphyrinogen III is converted to coproporphyrinogen III by decarboxylation of all of the acetate (A) groups, which changes them to methyl (M) substituent.
  • The reaction is catalyzed by uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.
  • This is also capable of converting uroporphyrinogen I to coproporphyrinogen I
  • This also takes place in the cytosol
  • Coproporphyrinogen III then enters the mitochondria, where it is converted to protoporphyrinogen III
  • The mitochondrial enzyme coproporphyrinogen oxidase catalyzes the decarboxylation and oxidation of two propionic side chains to form protoporphy- rinogen.
  • This enzyme is able to act only on type-III coproporphyrinogen, which would explain why type I proto- porphyrins do not generally occur in nature

Reference: Harpers illustrated biochemistry 30/ edition, page number 325-327

questions.text: A 6 year old child complaining of difficulty in walking and his walking style is changed. Clinician order a x ray and his x ray report is as follow. Which of the most common Nutrient deficiency occur in this child?
questions.solution:
The deficiency diseases are rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. Hence vitamin D is known as antirachitic vitamin.

Rickets is seen in children. There is insufficient mineralization of bone. Bones become soft and pliable. The bone growth is markedly affected.

The classical features of rickets are bone deformities. Weight bearing bones are bent. Continued action of muscles also cause bone malformations.

The clinical manifestations include bow legs, knock-knee, rickety rosary, bossing of frontal bones, and pigeon chest.

An enlargement of the epiphysis at the lower end of ribs and costochondral junction leads to beading of ribs or rickety rosary.

Harrison's sulcus is a transverse depression passing outwards from the costal cartilage to axilla.

This is due to the indentation of lower ribs at the site of the attachment of diaphragm.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry/ 30th edition, page number 553.
